Subject: English Language
Description: VCE English Language explores the ways in which language is used by individuals and groups and how it reflects our thinking and values.

Subject: English Language
Description: By learning about how we shape and can be shaped by our use of language, we can develop deeper understandings about ourselves, those who surround us and the society in which we live.

Subject: English Language
Description: These understandings enhance the skills for effective communication in all contexts.

Subject: English Language
Description: VCE English Language is informed by the discipline of linguistics and draws on a set of metalinguistic tools to understand and analyse language use, variation and change.

Subject: English Language
Description: It is a study that builds on our experiences of Standard Australian English (SAE) and language varieties across numerous contexts, including in the classroom.

Subject: English Language
Description: It connects directly with key concepts embedded in the Victorian Curriculum F–10: English, including the language modes, the roles played by context, purpose and audience in any engagement with text, and the ways in which textual form contributes to creating meaning.

Subject: English Language
Description: VCE English Language examines how use and interpretations of language are nuanced and complex rather than a series of fixed conventions.

Subject: English Language
Description: The study explores how we use spoken and written English to communicate, to think and innovate, to construct and reveal identities, to build and interrogate attitudes and assumptions, and to create and disrupt social cohesion.

Subject: English Language
Description: The study of VCE English Language reveals the structures, features and discourses of written and spoken texts through the systematic and evidence-based construction and deconstruction of language in use.

Subject: English Language
Description: The study of VCE English Language enables students to consider their understanding and application of English using a set of metalinguistic tools informed by the discipline of linguistics.

Subject: English Language
Description: This focus provides students with fresh insights into their language choices, the values and assumptions constructed when considering the language use of others, and the power of language to control, shape and disrupt our lives.

Subject: English Language
Description: Throughout their learning, students engage with the ways in which language is structured, the history of English and its variations both geographically and temporally, theories of language acquisition, variations of language created by social and cultural difference, the nexus between language and power, and the ways in which language can be used to construct and deconstruct identity.

Subject: English Language
Description: Students consider their own language use and the language use immediately surrounding them, as well as examples of language use locally, nationally and internationally.

Subject: English Language
Description: They explore the ways in which language use is adapted in consideration of formality, situational and cultural contexts, purpose and function.

Subject: English Language
Description: In this study students read widely to further develop their analytical skills and to build their understanding of linguistics.

Subject: English Language
Description: Students are expected to read and study a range of historical and contemporary texts, drawn from a variety of contexts and forms, including academic texts and publications.

Subject: English Language
Description: The study of VCE English Language enables students to further develop and refine their skills in reading, writing, speaking and listening to English.

Subject: English Language
Description: They become proficient in analysing and assessing language use and develop their abilities in effective communication.

Subject: English Language
Description: Through the exploration of language use, students gain insight into the experiences of others, develop empathy and compassion, and are better able to engage in active citizenship.

Subject: English Language
Description: This study enables students to:

Subject: English Language
Description: Appreciate the historical, social and cultural roles of language in their lives

Subject: English Language
Description: Describe and analyse the structures, features and functions of spoken and written English language using appropriate metalanguage

Subject: English Language
Description: Investigate language acquisition, language choice, use and variation, and language change over time

Subject: English Language
Description: Reflect on and evaluate attitudes to language in historical, contemporary and individual contexts, with particular focus on identity, social cohesion and the distinctiveness of Australian Englishes

Subject: English Language
Description: Explore and analyse the interplay between convention and creativity in language use

Subject: English Language
Description: Develop an awareness of the critical, intentional and innovative use of language and apply this to their own writing and speaking

Subject: English Language
Description: Become engaged, skilled and effective communicators.

Subject: English Language
Description: The study is made up of four units.

Subject: English Language
Description: Unit 1: Language and communication

Subject: English Language
Description: Unit 2: Language change

Subject: English Language
Description: Unit 3: Language variation and purpose

Subject: English Language
Description: Unit 4: Language variation and identity

Subject: English Language
Description: Each unit deals with specific content contained in areas of study and is designed to enable students to achieve a set of outcomes for that unit. Each outcome is described in terms of key knowledge and key skills.

Subject: English Language
Description: Units 1 and 2

Subject: English Language
Description: Procedures for the assessment of levels of achievement in Units 1 and 2 are a matter for school decision. Assessment of levels of achievement for these units will not be reported to the VCAA. Schools may choose to report levels of achievement using grades, descriptive statements or other indicators.

Subject: English Language
Description: Units 3 and 4

Subject: English Language
Description: The VCAA specifies the assessment procedures for students undertaking scored assessment in Units 3 and 4. Designated assessment tasks are provided in the details for each unit in VCE study designs.

Subject: English Language
Description: The student's level of achievement in Units 3 and 4 will be determined by School-assessed Coursework (SAC) as specified in the VCE study design, and external assessment.

Subject: English Language
Description: The VCAA will report the student's level of achievement on each assessment component as a grade from A+ to E or UG (ungraded). To receive a study score, the student must achieve two or more graded assessments in the study and receive an S for both Units 3 and 4. The study score is reported on a scale of 0–50; it is a measure of how well the student performed in relation to all others who completed the study. Teachers should refer to the current VCE Administrative Handbook for details on graded assessment and calculation of the study score.

Subject: English Language
Description: Percentage contributions to the study score in VCE English Language are as follows:

Subject: English Language
Description: Unit 3 School-assessed Coursework: 25 per cent

Subject: English Language
Description: Unit 4 School-assessed Coursework: 25 per cent

Subject: English Language
Description: End-of-year examination: 50 per cent.

Subject: English Language
Description: Details of the assessment program are described in the sections on Units 3 and 4 in this study design.
